awd_titl_txt: The Role of Copper and Transcriptional Regulatory Networks Governing Copper Homeostasis in Pollen Fertility in A. thaliana.
awd_abstract_narration:
The global demand for high-yielding crops is increasing due to current population growth, a trend that is forcing the utilization of marginal lands for agricultural purposes. For instance, limited copper availability in the soil causes copper deficiency in crop plants, a condition that leads to plant infertility and consequently low yields; however, total crop failure can be expected under acute copper deficiencies. Although a great deal is known about how plants acquire copper from the soil, and how it is mobilized within the plant, not much is understood about how copper affects plant fertility. This project will use interdisciplinary approaches to provide fundamental insights on the role copper plays in pollen development and fertility in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. More specifically, this project will also help to explain how two proteins, SPL7 and the newly discovered CITF1, coordinate copper uptake and delivery to the reproductive organs of A. thaliana, and how they orchestrate pollen development and fertility. This new knowledge and understanding will facilitate the development of crops with better grain yields in soils currently under cultivation or marginal soils. Research opportunities will be offered to undergraduate and graduate students with a special effort to attract women and underrepresented minorities. A multi-media web module "Mineral nutrition: from plants to humans" will be developed with the intent to increase the awareness of high school students and K-12 teachers about the role of micronutrients in plant growth and development as it pertains to food safety and human well-being. 


Although copper is recognized as an essential micronutrient for plant fertility, very little is known about copper delivery to reproductive organs, or about transcriptional regulatory networks that coordinate copper homeostasis and plant reproduction. In Arabidopsis thaliana, SPL7 is the only transcription factor known to function in copper homeostasis. This project is based on the recent discovery of CITF1 in the PI's lab. CITF1 is a member of the bHLH family of TFs that enables A. thaliana to survive copper deficiency. Preliminary evidence indicates that CITF1 interacts with the SPL7-pathway. Disrupting this interaction causes seedling lethality and pollen sterility. The sites of copper action in anthers and pollen, and the role played by SPL7- CITF1 in pollen development will be characterized through the analysis of mutant lines grown under different copper levels. Synchrotron X-ray fluorescent microscopy will be used to image (2D & 3D) copper distribution during pollen development. In-air scanning electron microscopy and histological analyses will be used to characterize copper-level effects on the anatomy and morphology of control and mutant lines. Targeted chromatin-immunoprecipitation and functional genetic assays will identify direct upstream regulators of CITF1. Global expression profiling coupled with computational co-expression network analyses will reveal likely downstream copper-responsive targets of SPL7 and CITF1, the hierarchy of regulatory components and their relationship to copper uptake, and organ partitioning and delivery. The long-term goals are to understand the regulatory and signaling networks underlying copper homeostasis, and to apply this knowledge to produce cultivars adapted to soils with low copper availability.

Project Outcomes:

 

Intellectual merit: The micronutrient copper (Cu) is required for nearly every aspect of the growth and development of all organisms including plants. Understanding Cu's role in reproduction requires special attention, considering the urgent demand for new, high-yield grain crops due to population growth and climate change pressures. Despite progress in tracing how Cu moves throughout the plant, scientists did not understand how Cu functions in reproduction, which reproductive organs require Cu, how Cu is delivered there, and how these processes are regulated. The results from this award provided a fundamental understanding of the role of Cu in reproduction, significantly advanced understanding of the transcriptional regulatory networks governing Cu homeostasis in plant growth, development, and fertility, and opened new avenues into the studies of the crosstalk between Cu and other minerals and plant hormones in plant developmental processes. These results are reflected in 10 publications; two more are in the pipeline.

 

Specifically, our lab identified and characterized a transcription factor CITF1 and showed that it regulates Cu uptake into roots and delivery to reproductive organs in Arabidopsis thaliana. We also showed that CITF1 acts in a complex integrated pathway with a previously characterized transcription factor SPL7. We found that the loss of CITF1 and SPL7 functions leads to seedling lethality unless the medium is supplemented with Cu. We found that Cu localizes to anthers, pistils, and pollen grains of A. thaliana; Cu delivery to these reproductive structures requires both CITF1 and SPL7 (Fig. 1A-C attached and [Rahmati Ishka et al., in preparation]); failure to deliver Cu to these reproductive structures in wild-type grown under acute Cu deficiency or in a mutant lacking both CITF1 and SPL7, results in female and male infertility (Fig. 1D attached). Male infertility of Cu-deficient A. thaliana or the citf1 spl7 double mutant is manifested by defects in anther development and pollen wall patterning (Fig. 2A, B attached), pollen tube growth (Fig. 2C, D attached) and anther dehiscence. Female infertility in Cu-deficient A. thaliana or spl7 single and the citf1 spl7 double mutant is associated with decreased stigmatic papillae length that leads to the inability of pollen to germinate on the stigma and develop a pollen tube for successful fertilization (Fig. 3 attached). These fertility defects phenocopy some of the defects of A. thaliana mutants with altered metabolism and/or signaling of the plant hormone auxin. A recently submitted grant application to NSF will explore an innovative hypothesis that Cu and the CITF1-SPL7-regulated pathway act in reproduction, in part, via auxin metabolism and/or signaling.  

 

We then used the yeast-one-hybrid assay to identify novel transcription regulators that control CITF1 expression and RNA-seq analyses to identify downstream CITF1 and SPL7 targets in reproductive organs. The Y1H screen identified fifteen transcription factors that bind to the promoter of CITF1. We will follow up on these findings via a new grant application. RNA-seq analysis disclosed that CITF1 regulates gene expression in developing flowers under control conditions, while its role in roots becomes more prominent under Cu deficiency. The number of SPL7-dependent genes was significantly higher in all tissues and growth conditions than the number of CITF1-dependent genes. Unlike Cu-responsive CITF1-regulated genes in flowers of A. thaliana, the number of Cu-deficiency-responsive SPL7-dependent genes was higher. Among downstream CITF1 and SPL7 targets were genes encoding characterized Cu-transporters (e.g., COPT1, COPT2, COPT3, YSL3). Transporters and transcription factor genes with unassigned functions identified in our RNA-seq analysis downstream of CITF1 and SPL7 will be investigated via the follow-up grant application.

 

Considering that CITF1 belongs to the basic-helix-loop-helix (bHLH) family of transcription factors whose members must form homo-or heterodimers to bind to DNA, we performed yeast-two-hybrid screen (Y2H) to identify CITF1 interacting partners. We found that CITF1 interacts with itself and a previously uncharacterized transcription factor, bHLH35, that we designated CIP1 (CITF1-Interacting Protein 1). The biological significance of CITF1-CIP1 interactions will be analyzed via a follow-up grant application. We also found that CITF1 interacts with FIT, a master regulator of Fe homeostasis (Fig. 4 attached). We have completed the analysis of the biological significance of CITF1-FIT interactions and are now preparing these data for publication (Fig. 5 attached).

 

Broader Impacts: In addition to increasing fundamental knowledge of the role of Cu in plant reproduction, this award trained undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs, including students underrepresented in STEM disciplines, in using cutting-edge techniques to address complex biological questions. Through the outreach activities, we developed educational videos about mineral nutrients and their role in plant growth, development, and fertility. We presented them annually to Ithaca High School students to initiate a conversation about the role of the adequate mineral nutrition of plants for the future of food security.
